author: dtor11

description.text:
More on the wiki : http://reprap.org/wiki/X-carriage-struder That's my vertical x-axis idea of a compact extruder integrated into the x-carriage, thanks to direct drive and linear bearings. It was designed for the "classic" Sells Mendel, as a sort of upgrade, but it's also compatible with the Prusa Mendel (same spacing between z-rods). The carriage-extruder is compatible with most of the existing hotends, or just ask for a diameter if your thermal break part (ptfe/peek) don't fit my 13mm. Recent History
[08/11] Replacing the old x-axis on my Sells Mendel by the VertX 0.7.3 (and major update of the wiki page)
[10/11] First print ! :D www.youtube.com/watch?v=6sF87FcMKyI
[13/11] x-carriage have mounting points now to accept more hotends
[30/11] V0.8 (x-carriage v12, x-end-idler-v9, x-end-motor-v8)

X-ends
2 perimeters for the x-ends will avoid small-segments-filling that can shake the bot.
"infill in direction of bridge" (in Carve) in case it's unchecked, that will make better closing for the bearings part. X-carriage
1 perimeter for the x-carriage
For the mendel-parts v6, the hole to mount the PEEK is 13mm, 18mm for the v9. See the wiki page for assembly instructions.

comments.text: I really like your vertical x-carriage design, so I'm using it in my early concept for a motor-less belt-driven extruder: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:15132http://www.thingiverse.com/thi...

comments.text: Thanks, I saw it the other day and I'm glad if other things can be build upon it :)
comments.author: Guest

comments.text: Have you tried the VertX with just a single threaded rod? I'm curious if the VertX is constrained enough by the vertical rods and lm8uu's to make it properly square, removing the need for the second lead screw, and allowing us to cheaply move to acme/trapezoidal thread.

comments.text: "by the vertical rod arrangement" i mean.

comments.text: Hmm no :o

comments.text: Interesting, the galileo's z-axis is only threaded rods and nuts, no bearings at all : http://reprap.org/wiki/Galileohttp://reprap.org/wiki/Galileo

comments.text: I printed the x-idler and I really like the design except the way that the smooth x rods connect.  I would use the type the prusa uses where there are bolt holes (not that I use bolts I stick a zip tie through each hole and it is a tight fit.)  Just my $0.02  What is this modeled in?  Would you be willing to share the files?
comments.author: Jolijar

comments.text: That's an interesting way to fit the rods :) Now that I built a emaker huxley I think I'll integrate some ideas of jeanmarc in my x-ends.
comments.author: Jolijar

comments.text: I printed one of the x carriages but the bearings had a hard time fitting in and its pretty brittle... only used 1 extra layer I'm printing another and increasing it to two layers... It looks good so far...
comments.author: Jolijar

comments.text: yep, I need to tweak them a little for the next revision ^^'
comments.author: Jolijar

comments.text: 2 extra layers works great the only problem I had with the print was the top (in relation to how it prints) there wasn't enough room for the top two bearings because the top retainer sagged so much I had to cut the whole thing out.  Also at the very top of the part I had the hole for the belt bearing deform because I forgot to turn cool on.  The part should still be useable though.  Perhaps give the top a little more surface area?
comments.author: watsdesign

comments.text: ah I see what you mean, indeed the upper part of the bearing holder of the x-carriage will sagg, I may try something different. I had also the same problem for the bearing hole, and had to file it
comments.author: Jolijar

comments.text: where did you source the gear that's on the stepper shaft?  Have you tested the extruder?  how well does it work?  What size are the bearings you used?  Have any videos of the setup printing?

comments.text: I like it. Looks a lot like what I had in mind for test tube mendel.  Between this and mixtape mendel, and the mystery russian Prusa, I think it's a good time to talk about standardizing rod spacing. That way extruders can be (probably)  interchangeable between any of the vertical x axis variants.

comments.text:
• Not yet, I first considered a tight-fit optino, or locking them with a bolt like on the prusa-x-ends, but I've also a version with clamp integrated (the x-ends are highly evolving atm : I printed the v2 idler here, but it's now in its 5th revision)

  • I wasn't sure to understand, but I got it ! I'll try to do make that (on my mendel the x-belt is bent in both direction, I assumed it was possible but if its better for its life it's preferable)

  • If we close the loop like on the open-x-carriage of Buback (with zip-tie) it's possible to use t
    he bearings on the x-carriage (or just a bolt) in a simple-resolution configuration (and thus having the choice^^)

  • I imagined to tighten the belt when hanging it on the x-ends (making a loop with a zip-tie), or by using the motor to tighten it like on the orca. I'll see :)

description.text: CO2 Flipper for fertilizing fish tank plants.

• Print without support and rasp the outer edge plain to let the bubbles run smoothly.

  • Guide the tube through the hole, then through the clamp and fix the clamp in the fitting of the inner side of the flipper.

  • For the cover I used a stub of a PET soft drink bottle with a approx. diameter of 60 mm or scale your print accordingly. The PET stub should have no profile.

  • Use a hair dryer to shrink the PET cover and it will tighten the flipper so no bubbles will escape through the edges.

  • Wash the item thoroughly with water and finally fill some gravel in the flipper to weight it down.
    • See it here in action:
    http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dfQ7tZzYggw

description.text: I skeinforged (41) this at 0.35mm layer 1.5/1.5 pwot/iwot with 100% fill at 48mm/sec feed.  I started printing it and it caused such bad shuddering on the small infill that it caused major missed steps and killed the print.  My sprinter accel settings are default.  I tried setting max start as low as 1 but that did not help...still need to try lowering the accel speeds.

comments.text: i actually wrote a patch to sprinter to help reduce the high frequency, yucky oscillations.  it's in sprinter experimental if you want to try it.  however, when i started using marlin, reduced my default accel down to 3000 or lower, and dropped my jerk to 15-20, no mas 'shuddering!' :)

title: End Stop Axis Z Steel Prusa

description.text:
Hi there, I decided to design an End Stop, Z Axis, for the Steel Prusa.
It requires a bit of sanding for a good fit on the contact parts with the printer frame. VERY VERY VERY IMPORTANT NOTE: When you touch the end stop switches pay particular attention at the connections. In particular pay attention that no wire gets detached from the switch itself, as if it makes a short you could fry the Ramps and the Arduino Mega.... and guess who have I learnt from?
The X Axis End Stop MOD costed me 35 Euros in Ramps/Arduino/1Driver.
So always be careful when you change pieces in your printer.... UNPLUG IT!
Extra things you need:
  • Screw + Nut
  • Cable Tie

author: Bibliotheekkopvanoverijssel

description.text: Attachment for a hand drill 1/4" hex shaft to twist wires together.

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Notes: I recommend using something strong & flexibile, like nylon. PLA will be too brittle and the posts will snap off.

Put a 1/4" hex shank bit in the center hole.  I used an old worn out #2 philips bit.  I recommend a bit that has a detent to prevent it popping out of the drill, if your drill supports it.  It should be a tight fit, but you may need to add glue if it's too loose.  If it's too tight, heat the bit with a torch for a few seconds and let it melt it's way into the plastic -- it will be very tight and secure.
Push alligator clips onto the posts  -- there are six posts so you can arrange them by 2, 3,  etc. You can use pliers to crimp them onto the posts or use glue if they come off.
Clip the wires to the alligators.
Hold or clamp the far end of the wires (by hand or in a vise) as you pull the trigger.
SPIN SPIN SPIN
A quick run over the twisted wires with a heat gun will "set" the twist. Be careful not to melt them!

title: Modern Knob for door or drawer

description.text:
Modern knob for door or drawer A cylindrical knob with a notch for a good finger grip.
Small footprint, quick printing time with no surprise, robust.
Fits 3.5 to 4.5mm wood screws (4 to 8 imperial gauge).
Can be tapped to fit M3 to M4 threaded screws (gauge 5 to 8 imperial). Mounting :
A logo at the top helps alling horizontaly : the loop must be down.
Pre drill a hole in the door or drawer front.
Pick preferabily a button head screw
It must runs freely thru the door or drawer hole.
Insert it into the hole.
Apply the knob end on the screw pin and start driving.
Before to lock the screw, check the knob is perfectly alligned.
If necessary rotate the knob to adjust it.
Then hold the knob firmly then tight the screw until it locks.
Don't overtight the screw. Enjoy.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Best print : 0.3mm Nozzle, 0.2 layers

Infill:

20 to 30% for extra strenght

Notes: Nozzle 0.3mm
Walls 1.2mm (4)
Plain top and bottom : 1.2mm (6) Any filament except flex filaments.
Extra strenght with nylon filaments.

2 coats of automotive plastic dressings. Avoid greasy dressings. My preference : Poorboy's World Natural look. Apply first coat,
Allow to cure for 5mn
Buff the excess with a microfibre towel
Allow to dry at last 30mn
Apply the seccond coat
Allow to cure for 5mn
Buff the excess with a microfibre towel
Allow to dry at last 30mn

Why this knob shape ? I wanted a simple and understandable shape oriented to function.
I believe if you keep things simple, It should fits in a large variety of situations.
I wanted that dimensions fits both a child or an adult hand, but keeping the knob as small as possible, to prevent clothes catching if you walk near the knob.
I wanted it small and elegant. So it can fit small to large drawers.
I designed the largest possible notch to allow a good grip without weaking the part.
I've tested it on large and heavy drawers up to 60mm (24") wide with no issue.
I believe the knob is strong enough to drive larger drawers,
but maybe you want to install 2 of it on large drawers for more comfort.
The last improvements was to make it smooth to the touch and comfortable. This is the V2 attempt, and probaby the ultimate one, because I've nothing to improve on it.

title: Customizable Pixel Clock Display with Std. LEDs

description.text:
Print your own large clock display with e.g 100mm (4") digit height using standard 5mm LEDs.
Use the customize feature to adapt to other digit height (grid size) or other LED diameters. You can also adapt spacer dimensions to fit in a picture frame.
Optimized for single extruder 3D printer. Print from LED-mount up. Add mounting spacers to fit in frame.

Diffusor For more and diffuse light paint inside with silver or white ink. For more diffuse lighting use LEDs with wide angle (straw hat) and/or sand the tip of the LEDs. As diffusor in front you can use a sheet of paper or an opal acryl.

Controller (Suggestion) To drive the LEDs use an Arduino with multiplexing in software or an integrated circuit MAX7219 (2 pcs) which handles the multiplexing in hardware. For higher power use a driver ULN2003 and/or UDN2981.
You can drive the multiplexing direct with an Arduino Uno or Nano for the 3x5-Display. For larger Display you need an Arduino Mega

title: Filament Guide to Prevent Binding for MakerBot Replicator 2

description.text:
This Thing guides the filament from the spool to the tube of the MakerBot Replicator 2.  It fixes the problem I've seen where the filament in a full spool jumps the spool wall and wraps around the axle.  
UPDATE: I've added a left-hand guide as well.

comments.text: This is particularly good if you use other brands of filament.

author: CustomAirSeals

description.text:
Six right handed and six left handed pieces are needed for this puzzle, it's not that difficult to figure out, but still an entertaining puzzle none the less. I included a 2 piece and a 4 piece design because when I tried to print more than 4 they warped too much by the time it was done printing. Either print 6 of the 2-piece stl, or 3 of the 4-piece stl, the sizes should be identical for the two stl files, so if it warps while printing 4 then try printing two at a time. Both stl files include an even number of right and left handed pieces.   
Enjoy the puzzle!

Helpful hint for sanding off the raft:
Two pieces connected directly over top of eachother makes it a nice easy rectangle to hold while sanding!

This fits the TeeCees with the PVC pipe fitting mount
I sliced in Slic3r with 15% infill honeycomb for the honey comb effect.

This is a case for a Motorola Razr that has a credit card slot for 2 cards (only works with 2 cards inserted.)

The phone pops in and stays nice and tight, the plastic extends above the phone to protect the screen.  All buttons/ports are usable and accessible with the case on except for microsd/sim card slot.  
File was designed in Autodesk Inventor 2013 original files not included, they are very messy and have a few dependencies.  
Enjoy.

author: jballard

description.text:
A 3-piece egg shaped birdhouse with built in rain catcher (1 degree tilt) filling two water bowls, a canopy, inner to outer extending perch, with m4 holes for an interior roosting perch, a drainage hole, and hanging loop. Diameter excluding the rain catcher is 150mm. The door hole is 40mm in diameter. Requires:
4x m3 10mm screws (1 for the perch, 3 for the top and bottom halves)
a stick, skewer or rod that's 4mm or less in diameter (for the roosting perch)
  • you could edit the SCAD file to make the holes larger
    • (I have not test printed any of these parts.... I did not account for all that weight in the front while designing, I will figure something out for that, but for now, perhaps a counter weight would do the trick) Which came first: the birdhouse or the egghouse? Update: I've finally printed one out, the walls are a tad too thin, the birdbaths may leak, but some glue or filler would take care of it.
    Printed: 3mm layers, 20% infill, no support, no raft

Use one 10mm m3 screw to mount the perching post onto the bottom half.
Use three 10mm m3 screws to mount the top half onto the bottom half.
Slip a rod of 4mm or less in diameter through the m4 holes for an interior roosting perch.
Hang your egghouse and watch the birds!

title: TARS Pebble time / time steel charging base

description.text:
Spanish (See below for english):
Esto es un cargador para el pebble time basado en la máquina TARS de la película 'Interestelar', que me gustó mucho. Como quería hacerme un cargador personal pensé: ¿porque no?. Necesitará dos tornillos M3x25 y tuercas para montarlo. Lo uso actualmente con mi pebble time steel, recuerda que el pebble time y el time steel tienen el mismo puerto en la misma posición. Opté por un sistema de hueco anti-deslizamiento que retiene el reloj en la plataforma del cargador (esto mantiene muy bien el reloj en su posición) colocado donde la TARS tiene su pantalla. Tuve que cortarle un poco una pierna a la TARS para que se pudiesen usar pulseras cerradas. También tuve que hacerla un poco mas baja para incrementar la estabilidad. He intentado ser fiel a las formas cuadradas de la TARS cuando ha sido posible. Es movil/configurable. Metes dentro el cable magnético y ocultas el cable en la parte de atrás de la pierna izquierda de la TARS. Las palabra 'TARS' está en relieve por si quieres usar un rotulador para pintarla. Tuve que ponerla en la pierna derecha para que fuera visible mientras se carga. Si no quieres que sea una TARS, simplemente no imprimas la pierna derecha. Impreso en plateado sería chulo, pero yo usé el plástico fosforescente que tenía puesto en la impresora. Disfrútalo! Actualización: (18-OCT-2015) Ajustados offsets. Añadidas fotos.
Actualización: (16-OCT-2015) Tolerancias mejoradas. Dos versiones del cuerpo, una para el pebble time y otra para el time steel. El time steel es un pelín más pequeño. English:
This a pebble time charger based on the TARS machine from 'Interstellar' movie, I liked it a lot. As I wanted to make myself a personal charger, so I thought: why not?. You'll need two M3x25 screws & nuts to assemble it. I am currently using it with my pebble time steel, remember the Pebble time and the time steel have the same port at the same location. I opted for a hollow anti-slip system that retains the watch on the charger platform (I think this keeps nicely the watch in place) placed where the TARS have its screen. Had to trim one leg of the thing to be able to use closed straps. Also had to scale it down to increase stability. Tried to be loyal to the squared forms of the TARS whenever possible. The thing is moveable/configurable. You just slip inside the magnetic cable head and hide the rest of the cable into the back side of the TARS left 'leg'. The TARS name is on relief in case you want to use a sharpie to color it, had to put it on the right 'leg' to keep it visible while charging. If you don't want it to be a TARS, simply don't print the right leg thingie. Printed with a silvery plastic would be cool, but I used the phosphorescent plastic I had on the printer. Enjoy! UPDATE: (18-OCT-2015) Offsets adjusted. Pics added.
UPDATE: (16-OCT-2015) Improved tolerances. Two versions of the body, one for the pebble time and another for the Pebble time steel. Steel version is a bit smaller.

title: E3Dv6 fan shroud for Printrbot with new hotend adapter

description.text: Modified the Simonwlchan excellent shroud to fit with tonyyoungblood's e3dv6 spacer. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:958450 Also removed some extra design elements to print a bit faster. Added a picture of the bridge-torture-test_50mm after installing this fan. Probably should lower the temperature a touch more, but it came out pretty damn great.

Please use fan-shroud-v2 with the spacer. After running with the new spacer I built, the previous shroud kept hitting the bed and bulldozing the filament off, the only way to stop that was by filing the shroud down. So instead I opted to redevelop the shroud. 
With the latest changes, I shortened the length of the shroud's nozzle so it no longer hits the bed. I also widened the mouth and pointed it down. The air flow hits right below the hot end's nozzle with a wider pattern. Prior it seemed to hit the nozzle and was more focused. 
You can see the new picture of the bridge-torture-test_50mm and it's improved, no slouching on the bottom of the bridge at all. I call that a complete success and improvement. Again, thanks to Simonwlchan for making the original shroud this remix is based off.
Both shrouds were printed with PETG natural. The newer shroud is even clearer due to slimming the walls a bit more.
Lastly, I added my own adapter for the e3d, seems the other sizes are either too tall or too short, this seems to be just right and gives a snug fit. Please note, that the filament hole for the spacer is sized so the PTFE Liner can be cut and butt up against the metal extruder (check pictures). Which helps with printing flexible filament such as ninjaflex.

author: winston

description.text:
I made this clamp knob using the customizer and http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:713300. I wanted the 1/4-20 nut to be trapped inside, so I modified the knob to do that. Print with the larger surface down. The last layer of the nut trap is at 9mm, so edit your g-code by searching for G1 Z9 - it should find a line like G1 Z9.000 (this could be different, depending on your layer heights. I printed with .3 layer height, so Z9.000 was exact for me). On the line before this one, enter @pause. The print will now pause before printing the layer that starts closing the nut trap. While paused, lower the bed (G1 Z100) and drop a 1/4-20 nut into the knob and then hit resume. I made these to go with these other pieces to use with my MP CNC. MP CNC (amazing!) - http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:724999
T-slots for 1/4-20 carriage bolts - http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:876395
Hold down - http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:21057

When dry the glass case can be lifted of the 3d printed platform and the Destroyer can be safely put into the display. Goodluck. 0.1 mm resolution is recommended to get the text nice.

title: HTC Evo 3D extended battery case

description.text: So, I like cellphone cases. I like to protect my cellphone. It's all and well if you use the default battery size. For extended batteries, it's really hard to find cases that are made for them. 3rd party extended batteries differ in shape and size. I had a HTC Evo previously and I shelled out the money for a Sedio extended battery plus case, but they're expensive. With my Evo 3D, I decided to get a cheaper extended battery. It's this kind: http://www.amazon.com/Trexcell-3500mah-Extended-Battery-Cover/dp/B004XM9V1K There are no cases for it, so I decided to make one on SolidWorks. Of course, this part is useful for only people who have an Evo 3D with that specific extended battery.
Print out the case, pop your Evo 3D in!

author: xeijix

description.text:
Hi guys! :]
We would like to share with You our latest baby ;)
It's a 3D Virtual Reality Headset that's like no other! In the era of super advanced gadgets like Oculus and Gear VR we have decided to go a little back in time to have an oldschool stereoscopic fun! You can create your own 3D images, print VR glasses and have a lot of fun!!!

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Notes: The design is super-simple. All the parts are almost 100% flat so everything is super-easy to print. The only parts we couldn't print by ourselves are a standard 25mm Google Cardboard VR lenses (easy to find on ebay...) and a couple of rubber bands :]

TIP 3: there are many other ways to create stereoscopic slides. In our work we used mainly professional 3D software such as Autodesk 3DS Max, Maxon Cinema 4D and Otoy Octane Render. However, internet is full of easy to use apps that will help you make your own creations such as 3defy (http://www.3defy.com) You can see FVR in action here:
(polish is a beautiful language isn't it? ;)))

We started our work with analisys of Google cardboard VR. It is a great tool however we wanted to create something a little bit different... We wanted to bring back the excitement of childhood, retro, low-fi, stereoscopic gadgets ;) Our goal was to create about 300 FVR units. Therefore we had to optimize the design in terms of cost effectivnes and prepare it to semi-mass production techniques. The hard part was to replace pretty expensive transparent slides with a standard paper printed photos. We achieved it by designing a light, open structure body. After a number of handmade and digital prototypes we finally came up with a final design :] It was a relatively short but very interesting and fun project :]

And now the really fun part! You can do whatever You want with our FVR! Thanks to modular, non rigid, flexible design, one of our collegues managed to hack FVR by simply using larger rubber band! He showed us how easy it is to attach ANY KIND of smartphone and use FVR as a regular 3D VR glasses! You can use it in the same way as Google cardboard VR, Samsung Gear VR or anything else and experience VR apps, 360 degree movies, 3D content and more! :]

comments.text: This looks amazing, and it's obvious you put a lot of time into it! I'm starting to print the parts now, and I ordered some lenses from Amazon. Thanks for posting this! It's the only VR headset I've found that can fit on my printer's bed. (I intend to use this for VR with my OnePlus One)

description.text:
Here is my 3D printed tricopter. It has been a work in progress that was placed on the back burner as I got busier with work. I am publishing it now as it is in very good working order. There are a few up and coming modifications that will improve both this thing and my 3D printed Quadcopter. I am very happy with the way things worked out with this design and am happy to have a tricopter back in my fleet. The tricopter was, after all, my first love in the world of multi-rotors. So here it is. Feel free to build, modify, provide feedback and of course fly!
If you enjoy my designs a small donation is greatly appreciated! Donate Update 8/14/13: If anyone if looking to use a CCD camera instead of a GoPro check out this thing http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:133200 Update 6/30/13: I have deleted the links to HobbyKing.com because their links always seem to change. A quick search for any of the components on HobbyKing or google should return good results. Sorry for the inconvenience.

1.) Print all plates at minimum 20% infill with 2 shells.
2.) Print motor mounts at 50% infill.
3.) Print spacers at minimum 25% infill.
4.) Print Servo mount and 20% infill.
5.) Carbon tubes are sandwiched between the spacers and motor mounts can be secured using a drop or two to superglue or a set screw. I sourced Most of this stuff from Hobbyking, but try http://www.getfpv.com for your electronics. They are a great one stop shop for multirotors and FPV. Electronics List:
Motors - NX-4008-620kv ESCs - Turnigy Plush 30A Battery - Turnigy Nanotech 3S or 4S 4000mah Flight Controller - KK 2.0

comments.text: I drew the GT2 profile carefully according to the standard, but its efficiency varies of course on every printed part; Other than that, increasing the normal pressure is the only way to improve grip. Check that the flat side of the belt is not loose, - there are thinner belts than others -, if so you could add a tiny cardboard piece under it to tighten everything up. But if the clip (even printing it a bit smaller, say 95% to tighten the piece) fails at that, you could try with one or two zipties instead of it. Or even a drop or two of cement inside the teeth cavity.  Or everything together. Uglier for sure, but, it may work ... ;-) Thanks for your comment!

With enough adherence between layers they should do the trick. Thanks for pointing it and good luck!
comments.author: wkearney99

comments.text: I printed them 'flat on their back' with the J prongs facing up like U-shape.  That seemed to work.  But it occurs to me that leaves a problem with the layers being aligned along the very edge that's going to see stress.  As in, I just sheared the hook off one of them because of that.  Could be my ham-fisted handling of them too.
comments.author: stratop80

comments.text: Just redid them on a better raft, on their sides and they came out great.  Now I just need those long screws to show up...
comments.author: wkearney99

comments.text: Nah, dont worry, you'll get it sure this time. ;-) I added an image to show what I think its the best way to print it, so that the "fibers" of filament take account of the tension. I think the photo shows too the same configuration if you look it closely. Check settings toimprove adherence and to avoid delamination. Also, being such a tiny piece, you might print more than one at a time, or print other things alongside it, so that each layer has time to cool down a little, before the hotend returns to attack next layer too soon and damage the piece. Thanks, best luck!

title: Solidoodle front side hot end retainer

description.text:
For those who removed the wooden plate from their solidoodle extruder and found the hot end wobbly at times. This thing will secure the hot end from the front, basically completing the ledges from the sides and back. It uses the two existing bolts that attach the extruder to the x axis carriage to attach itself in turn to the extruder. Update:
The reason I discarded the wooden mount was for convenience - to easily unmount the hot end. With this retainer I am not wholly happy that I have to remove 3 screws to un-mount the hot end. So I designed an alternate retainer that is attached to the jigsaw with only one screw - the one you have to remove anyway because it is pinching the hot end to the jigsaw. I added the new stl to same thingiverse thing, not replaced it, so the old thing is still available.

comments.text: I removed the wooden thing, but I replaced it with a FR5 PCB...

Mother's request. A two-part mold for making shot glasses made of ice.
Simple: Pour water into container until it leaks out the three relief canals at the top (be sure you're doing this over a sink or something you don't mind getting wet.) Then put the top on so that the three notches line up with the holes. Wipe the sides of the mold dry and put in freezer until frozen and carefully remove shot glass.
Makes and photos yet to come. Examples and feedback from others are appreciated. Enjoy!

Easily convert any household lemon into an Aperture Sciences combustible lemon, courtesy of Cave Johnson's Engineers. If you have no idea what is going on, watch this:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NyLUU3O4zW8 Printed on an early Fablicator.
www.fablicator.com

Print both pieces, snap together.
Cut a small piece off the top of a lemon.
Use a 2.5" drywall screw to attach the detonator to the lemon on the newly created flat.
Insert appropriately sized spring in the other hole (about 3/16" OD x .75" long, fairly weak)
Bend a pin out of whatever ~1/16" OD metal is lying around (I used piano wire)
Close handle, insert pin.
Burn life's house down at your convenience
Note: The solidworks files for the handle and detonator are exported from the "lemon" multi-body part file. You should download all 3 files if you want to try and edit this.

120mm x 90mm large monstrous creature bases; primarily used for a new Tyranid army. Scale as needed; could work well as scatter terrain. Add as much flock, grit/sand, body bits and slime to your hearts content... prints without support; 
The bases are entirely flat on the bottom without the customary raised indentation. A raised indentation could be added to allow pins to extend below the base or weights to be added underneath however it would then require supports to print. I've pinned models directly to the raised terrain areas on the base - rocks, side walls, eggs, et.al. Use a small pin drill to create a hole where you need and add a few drops of super glue in the hole before inserting the pin.

title: Poorly Hacked NEMA 17 Stepper Upgrade for Mk5

description.text: Goal: combine Ruttmeister's NEMA 17 gear set with ScribbleJ's Wade's-Style Tensioner. I tried the Nearly Universal Adaptor Plate (thing:6458), but ran into two problems: it didn't fit on my platform, and â€” when I printed it with half the stepper bracket removed â€” didn't provide enough spacing for thing:5795's 51-tooth and 14-tooth NEMA 17 gears. Similarly, Ruttmeister's official bracket wouldn't fit on my platform. Lacking the OpenSCAD skills, and with my extruder disassembled, I bought some aluminium L bracket and hacked this together. it uses thing:6458 with everything that doesn't match ScribbleJ's original design cut off with a hacksaw. This isn't the ideal shape of the bracket, by any means. I took some measurements, hacked this thing together, and then made the design in Sketchup.

Print the 51-tooth and 14-tooth NEMA 17 gears from thingiverse.com/thing:5795 Print ScribbleJ's tensioner and block from thingiverse.com/thing:6402 Hack into some aluminium bracket with hacksaw, drill, and Dremel. I've shown my steps on Flickr: http://bit.ly/mSIwlH Profit!

title: Functional Rick and Morty Portal Gun Prop Mk 2

description.text:
Second version of my Rick and Morty Portal Gun (link below). Still a WIP!
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:981091 Git Repo:
https://github.com/mrmoss/portal_gun_mk2 Current BOM:
Arduino Pro Mini https://www.adafruit.com/products/2378
Battery Management https://www.adafruit.com/products/2465
Sound Board https://www.adafruit.com/products/2217
Joystick https://www.adafruit.com/product/512
LEDs https://www.adafruit.com/products/1612
Switch https://www.adafruit.com/products/805
Display https://www.adafruit.com/products/878
FTDI https://www.adafruit.com/products/284
LiIon battery https://www.adafruit.com/products/1781
Jumpers https://www.adafruit.com/products/266
Speaker https://www.adafruit.com/products/1891
T10 Lightbulb Walmart/Lowes/Home Depot In addition to the above parts, you probably want a piece of stripboard or a tie down plate for VCC and GND breakout. There are 8 wires by my count that are not VCC/GND...so this is a substantially easier wiring job than the previous Mk 1. The price is also about 5 times as much as the original...but the parts are "source-able" and "not-from-a-dumpster"... New Functionality:
Real Sounds (Plug in sound board, upload sound files).
Less Wires (Mainly a display breakout).
Joystick (Not canon per-say...but in an alternate universe...alt-Rick used a joystick...).
Rechargeable (Power board plugs into USB to charge).

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

10%

The joystick shield has three main components:
  • Actual Joystick Assembly
  • Board
  • Rubber Thumb Thingy
    • Start by putting the assembly into the board. Flip it over. I usually solder the diagonals to make sure it is seated properly. Solder the rest of the pins. I completely forgot to take a picture of the wires...and it is now glued into the handle... Grab 5 female to female jumpers. Cut one end off and solder them to the pads. I used the following color code:
    Red - 5V
    Yellow - XOut
    Yellow - YOut
    Green - Select
    Black - Ground Make sure these are around 6-8 inches long. Really short wires makes end assembly fairly hard (you'll find out why later in the instructions. Hot glue the leads down to the board for strain relief (if I don't do this...the wires ALWAYS come undone...). Tape the two yellow and the 1 green jumpers together.

For use with the Mk1 stls, you can use the rotary encoder board. First we need to clip off the male headers. If we don't do this, the board doesn't fit into the slot. Grab some jumpers, clip them in half, strip the ends, and tin them. Now comes the wird part...note how the wires are soldered? The board isn't long enough on one side, so we need to run the wires from this side of the board. Black - Ground
Red - 5V
Blue - SW
Yellow - DT
Yellow - CLK Hot glue the wires to make sure they stay. Test fit, seems to work. Plug it in, here there is an extra step. There are two defines at the top of firmware.ino. Change the two lines from: #define JOYSTICK //#define ENCODER to: //#define JOYSTICK #define ENCODER

The speaker wires are fairly dinky...I replaced mine with some 18 gauge wire I had laying around. Note: The sound board in the image below is not the one used in this project! I forgot to take pictures of the wire connectors on the sound board...but the connectors connect-together. Then put them in the holes on the sound FX board (they only fit in the one place). Adafruit has a great tutorial on using this board: https://learn.adafruit.com/adafruit-audio-fx-sound-board Use the screw down terminals to connect the speaker.

For the power switch, start by grabbing two pieces of wire (2-3 inches long). Strip and tin the exposed parts. Cut one leg off the switch (not necessary...but the less metal things that can accidentally touch two traces or components and short them...the better...). Solder the two wires to the switch. Feel free to used heat shrink as well.

There are two components to the display:
  • 4 Digit 7 Segment Display
  • I2C Backpack
    • Make sure you get the display in correctly (the orientation is on the silk screen). Again, start with the diagonals to make sure it is seated correctly. Once seated correctly, solder the rest of the pins. It's not in the image below, but clip off the excess leads. Grab 4 jumpers, clip off one side. I used the following color code:
    Red - 5V
    Black - Ground
    Blue - SDA
    Blue - SCL Solder the jumpers to the board. Hot glue the leads down to the board for strain relief (again, if I don't do this...the wires ALWAYS come undone...). Tape the blue pins together.

Grab a vice or clamp, super glue, the handle halves, and the box piece. After removing the support material, glue the halves together and put them in the vice/clamp. I also put the handle in the box piece to let it dry (this way everything lines up). Note: I did not use supports on the handle halves...you should... You may want to skip this step just to make sure your wiring is 100% correct before you hot glue something in. Take the joystick assembly and put it in the slot. I put it in sideways because the actual mechanical assembly isn't as wide vertically when it is in this orientation. Getting it lined up can be tricky, so use a little bit of hot glue, assemble everything, and see if it is lined up. If it is, add enough hot glue to make it stay in. Note: The gaps are actually ok (that's the fill, sand, prime, fill, sand, prime, fill, sand, prime, fill, sand, prime, fill, sand, prime, ... step).

I could have done a much better job of documenting this project. I did some experimenting during this process, and didn't really know what I was going to do until the end. All of the boards in this project come with male headers. I used these headers to connect everything together. Pinout is in the next section below. Once everything is together like above, grab a piece of cardboard (really anything flat that isn't conductive) and seat all of your electronics to it. I uploaded the sound file (in the files section, T08.ogg) before gluing everything down. Note: Stripboard would have been better to use instead of the soldered breadboard... It's amazing how much use the sticky note below gets in the office...

To test your code, download the Arduino IDE (1.6.5 added a library manager...I love it so much...words cannot express how happy I am about this...). Add the following libraries from Sketch>Include Library>Manage Libraries:
Adafruit NeoPixel Library
Adafruit LED Backpack Library
Adafruit GFX Library If you are using the rotary encoder:
Encoder Open and upload the tester program (files section, tester.zip). This program spits out the sum of the analog joysticks to the display, lights up the LEDs and plays the sound when the joystick button is clicked down.

I had a question asking if the Mk1 print could be used with the newer hardware. With the display below, it sure can! Old display with backpack:
https://www.sparkfun.com/products/11441 Same process with an extra step. First, grab some jumpers Tin the wires and solder them to the correct pads. Hot glue for securing. Plug it in, here there is an extra step. There are two defines at the top of firmware.ino. Change the two lines from: #define ADAFRUIT_7SEGMENT //#define SPARKFUN_7SEGMENT to: //#define ADAFRUIT_7SEGMENT #define SPARKFUN_7SEGMENT

This is by far the most dangerous part of this project. I wore full face protection, gloves, and a thick jacket. I've never had the light bulb I use explode...but I prefer to be paranoid over having shards of glass in my eyes. I use T10 lightbulbs for these. You can find them at pretty much any grocery store. Mark a spot approximately 1.5 inches from the bottom of the screw in part. With a dremel, carefully score the line over and over again. Sooner or later, the bulb will just come apart. The bulb halves have sharp edges! Be careful! After cutting, there is an obvious jagged glass problem. Not to mention you might get a split starting. I superglue the split (so it doesn't split more) and put electrical tape around the jagged edges. Do a test fit (note, I noticed the ring model was missing...not sure how I forgot this...).

Onto the dome LED. Neopixels are great for projects because they use 1 wire for more or less as many as you want (excluding 5V and ground) in a daisy chaining fashion. Snap off one of the neopixels. For the dome, you really want some sort of white colored wire. I recently noticed the portal gun actually has a swirlly-thingy instead of a crystal-thingy...so I'm going to shoot for the swirlly-thingy this time around. Tin the wires and tin the pads for the wires. Make sure you tin the side that has DIN. This LED will be the last LED in the daisy chain, so it HAS to be DIN. Solder on the wires. I want the LED to be the center of the swirlly-thingy, so I put the wires near the center of it. Before we get to the messy part, mark the other end of the wires so you know which s 5V, ground, and DIN. I used solid-back for ground, dashed black for 5V, and no marking for DIN. At this point, you may want to test this LED before moving on to the next part. To do this, load up the test program and hookup 5V to 5V, ground to ground, and DIN to pin 10 on the Arduino. Hold down the joystick button to see the LED light up. Now onto the messy part. Grab a hot glue gun and put on a thing layer all around the LED. Grab another piece of white wire (or use fishing line maybe?). Add it to the top of the LED. Add another layer of hot glue. Now add a bit of hot glue to the tip of the monstrosity and touch it to the top of the dome. Once it dries, bend the wires over and hot glue those to the base of the dome. Swirlly-thingy achieved.

I filled my dome up with a clear acrylic resin (links below). I like this stuff because it doesn't smell very bad initially...but as it cures...it does. This way, you can mix it and such in your shop/home, and then stick it outside to cure overnight. I used a drill press vice to hold the bulb in place while filling it. http://www.michaels.com/castin-craft-clear-polyester-casting-resin-32-oz/10558122.html
http://www.michaels.com/castincraft-catalyst/10558155.html Before placing the bulb half in the vice, wrap it in a double up folded paper towel. Try not to over tighten the bulb in the vice. This resin looks like a strange color when you pour it in, but it comes out pretty clear. I wanted bubbles in this mixture. To do this, do everything your not supposed to do:
-Add half a teaspoon of water to the mix.
-Poor it in as much as you can as fast as you can.
-Do not shake the piece to drive the air bubbles out. Below is the finished product. I realized my initial design wasn't going to work. So we need to add some female jumper ends to the wires we have on the dome. When splicing wires, having some shrink tubing really makes a big difference, but tape will work as well. MAKE SURE TO LOOK AT THE NEW PINOUT ABOVE! Start by making the wires on the dome a little shorter. I'm always cautious to cut things too short...so leave a good 2 inches. Tin both sides of the wires and solder them together. If you are using shrink tubing, make sure you have it on before you start soldering. Once you have them soldered on, apply some heat to the heat shrink and we're all done with this piece.

Finally got around to designing the front panel. Grab 3 more of the Neopixels and a hot glue gun as well. The Neopixels should almost snap into place in the square holes on the back of the plate. Make sure they are all facing the same direction! Hot glue around the Neopixels to keep them in place. Tin all of the contacts. Find some extra wire (or cannibalize some jumpers). Solder the wires onto the Neopixels We need some actual female jumpers to connect it to the main board. Solder those in on the DIN side. At this point, test this out by plugging the DIN pin to the Arduino 13, GND to the GND rail on the strip board, and 5V to the 5V rail on the strip board. Try a test fit! The switch will be hot glued on once it is painted and such. It may be wise to take the Neopixels out before sanding and painting (greatest things about hot glue...you can disassemble if you have to. I may not sand this side and just paint it. The switch should be a friction fit.

Assembly actually has to happen in a fairly specific order, especially once the handle piece is glued in. That'll be next! Note: The final build will not have scotch tape holding it together. Also, this thing looks really great in the dark...blindingly great...

Here grab some Elmer's wood filler, sand paper, and some small files. The filler goes on purple and turns white when it is dry. I tend to put on a ton of this stuff and sand it smooth. You can do this as many times as you want, sooner or later you've got to call it quits. Once you've had enough sanding, apply a coat of white spray primer and then 2 coats of silver spray paint.

Apply some hot glue to the bottom of the electronics "board" and glue it in place inside of the gun.

Hot glue the ring onto the "crystal" thing we made before.

Plug the crystal thing in and put it into the frame. Mine stays in place without any glue, apply some if needed.

Plug the front panel in and screw it into the frame. You can either use some tiny #2 self-tapping machine screws or drill and tap and use 4-40 or M3.

Turn it on, enjoy.

It looks pretty cool in the dark too.
